questions.text: Which of the following is true about vaginal changes in a normal pregnancy?

choices.text: Increased glycogen metabolism in the epithelium

questions.solution:
There is an increase in the metabolism of glycogen in the vaginal epithelium during normal pregnancy.

The changes in the vagina during pregnancy include:

  • Increased vascularity and hyperemia resulting in a violet/purplish color characteristic of Chadwick's sign
  • Vaginal epithelium undergoes marked proliferation (option D) with the extension of the squamocolumnar junction downwards
  • Vaginal pH decreases and becomes more acidic (option C) and varies from 3.5-6.0.
  • Increase in the number of Lactobacillus acidophilus (option A). It metabolizes the glycogen stores and causes an increased production of lactic acid. Therefore, the pH becomes acidic.
  • Increased volume of cervical secretion during pregnancy results in the production of thick white vaginal discharge.

questions.text: In pregnancy, vaginal cytology shows a predominance of _____.
questions.solution:
During pregnancy, vaginal cytology shows a predominance of intermediate cells.

Related Pearl: Cytohormonal study of the vaginal epithelium

Layer Cell characteristics Hormones Age of the woman
Parabasal and basal Small, round and basophilic with large nuclei Lack of hormonal activity

Childhood until puberty

Menopause with atrophy
Intermediate cells

Transparent and basophilic (blue-green) with vesicular nuclei

 Progesterone, Androgen, Corticosteroid 

Pregnancy

At an early transition of  menopause
Superficial cells Large cells with a pyknotic nucleus, acidophilic on staining Estrogen

Reproductive period

Preovulatory phase

Note: Malignant cells contain less cytoplasm, and hyperchromatic nuclei which are variable in size.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman has come for pre-conceptional counselling. Her BMI is 30 kg/m2 and she is worried about weight gain during pregnancy. How much weight should she gain during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The patient in the given question is obese. The recommended gestational weight gain in such a patient is 5-9 kg. 

Ideally, weight gain should depend on the pre-pregnancy BMI (body mass index) level. The gestational weight gain recommended for each BMI category by the Institute of Medicine (IOM) are as follows: 

Category

BMI (in kg/m2)

Recommended weight gain

Underweight

<18.5

12.5–18 kg

Normal

18.5–24.9

11.5–14 kg

Overweight

25–29.9

7–11.5 kg

Obese

>30

5-9.1 kg

questions.text: In pregnancy, the diaphragm is elevated by ____.
questions.solution:
The diaphragm is elevated by 4 cm in pregnancy.

The anatomical changes in the respiratory system during pregnancy are:

  • Elevation of diaphragm by 4 cm
  • Transverse diameter of chest increases by 2 cm
  • Chest circumference increases by 5-7 cm
  • Subcostal angle increases from 68 degrees to 103 degrees

questions.text: A pregnant woman at her 30th week of pregnancy undergoes a pulmonary function test. Provided there is no respiratory abnormality, which of the following would be decreased?
questions.solution:
Functional residual capacity decreases in pregnancy.

The changes in the respiratory system during pregnancy are:

Increase

Decrease

Unaffected
  • Tidal volume
  • Inspiratory capacity
  • Minute O2 uptake
  • Minute ventilation
  • Functional residual capacity
  • Expiratory reserve volume
  • Residual volume
  • Total lung capacity
  • Respiratory rate
  • Vital capacity
  • Inspiratory reserve volume 

(Mnemonic: TIMM increases in pregnancy)

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about prolactin levels in pregnancy?

choices.text: Lowest in pregnancy and increases after delivery
Highest at term and reduces after delivery
Increases during pregnancy and plateaus during lactation

questions.solution:
The maternal plasma prolactin level is highest at term and reduces after delivery. Despite this high level, milk secretion does not occur during pregnancy due to the action of estrogen and progesterone.

Prolactin secretion returns to the nonpregnant level a few weeks after delivery. The levels of estrogen and progesterone fall and hence, prolactin can promote milk secretion even at a lesser concentration.

questions.text: Which of the following produce estrogen and progesterone in the first two months of pregnancy?
questions.solution:
In the first two months of pregnancy, estrogen and progesterone are produced by the corpus luteum.

It functions maximally during the second month of pregnancy and thereafter contributes relatively little. Estrogen is synthesized in the placenta from the 7th week and progesterone from the 8th week.

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents to an antenatal clinic for the first time during the second trimester. In view of a family history of thyroid disorders, a thyroid function test is sent for. Altered levels of which of the following would not be a cause for concern?
questions.solution:
Total T3 levels are altered throughout pregnancy.

Total T3 and total T4 increase due to stimulation of thyroid tissue by hCG during the early period of gestation. However, there is no change in free T3 and T4 due to an increase in thyroid-binding globulin (TBG).

This leads to a transient fall in TSH during the early weeks of gestation. The level of TSH becomes normal during the second and third trimester. 

Hormone secretion during pregnancy:

  • Increased
    • GH
    • Insulin
    • Prolactin
    • Aldosterone
    • Testosterone
    • Total T3, T4
  • Decreased
    • LH
    • FSH
    • DHEAS (dihydroepiandosterone)
  • Unchanged
    • TSH
    • ADH (vasopressin)
    • Free T3, T4

questions.text: Which of the following do not synthesise relaxin during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Relaxin is not synthesised by the fetal adrenal gland in a pregnant woman. It is synthesised by corpus luteum, decidua and placenta. 

Relaxin is a placental protein hormone. Plasma levels peak between 8 and 12 weeks of gestation and decline thereafter to lower levels that persist until term.

Functions of relaxin are:

  • Relaxation of myometrium and quiescence of early pregnancy
  • Enhancement of the glomerular filtration rate
  • Endometrial vascular remodelling by inducing secretion of VEGF

questions.text: Which among the given features is not a major physiological change in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Among the given features hypothyroidism is not a major physiological change in pregnancy.

The α-subunits of hCG and TSH are identical. An increase in hCG during pregnancy stimulates thyroid and leads to a decrease in TSH levels. The thyroid undergoes enlargement and boosts the production of hormones. This is accompanied by increased production of thyroid-binding globulin(TBG). All these changes increase total T4 and T3 in the first trimester. But the physiologically important free T4 and T3 levels remain unchanged. Hence, physiologically pregnant women remain euthyroid.

Option A: Normal pregnancy is characterized by insulin resistance and hyperinsulinemia. Human placental lactogen(hPL) secreted during pregnancy, helps in adaptation to fetal energy requirements. Insulin resistance causes prolonged hyperglycemia and glucose flow to the fetus. It also favours protein synthesis. To counterbalance the increased insulin resistance and prevent maternal hyperglycemia, maternal insulin levels are increased.

Option B: By the 3rd trimester, there is an increase in the maternal basal metabolic rate by 10 to 20% in comparison to a nonpregnant woman.

Option D: During normal pregnancy, mean arterial pressure and vascular resistance decrease, while blood volume and cardiac output rate increase. This helps in meeting metabolic demands of the enlarged uterus, provide nutrients to rapidly growing placenta and fetus, safeguard mother against the effects of parturition-associated blood loss.

questions.text: A pregnant woman with diabetes mellitus is advised to increase her insulin dose as pregnancy is characterised by insulin resistance. Which of the following is not implicated in this phenomenon?
questions.solution:
hCG is not implicated in insulin resistance during pregnancy.

As the fetus is dependant on maternal glucose for sustenance, the blood glucose levels are maintained at a high level in the mother. In response to this, the insulin level in the mother increases, which reduces the maternal blood glucose. To counteract this, the placenta secretes certain hormones which increase insulin resistance in the mother. This resistance is maximal between 24 to 28 weeks. 

Hormones increasing insulin resistance include:

  • Human placental lactogen - Increases lipolysis and liberation of free fatty acids
  • Progesterone and estrogen
  • Placental growth hormone - Major determinant of maternal insulin resistance after mid-pregnancy
  • Cortisol
  • Prolactin

questions.text: Which of the following changes are not seen in the renal system during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Serum creatinine levels decrease during normal pregnancy from a mean of 0.7 mg/dL to 0.5 mg/dL.

Physiological changes in the renal system during pregnancy include:

  • Increase in:
    • Renal blood flow(+80%)
    • GFR(+50%)
    • Creatinine clearance
    • Glucosuria
  • Decrease in:
    • Plasma osmolality
    • Creatinine
    • Uric acid
    • Na/K/Cl 

Anatomical changes in the renal system during pregnancy include:

  • Both kidneys enlarge by 1 cm
  • Hydroureter and hydronephrosis - More common on the right side due to dextrorotation of the uterus
  • Congestion of the bladder causing decreased bladder capacity
  • Increased bladder pressure and intraurethral pressure

questions.text: Which of the following is increased during pregnancy?

choices.text: Total oxygen carrying capacity of blood

questions.solution:
The total oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood increases during pregnancy.

During pregnancy, there is an increase in total haemoglobin (Hb) resulting in increased total oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood. However, there is a relative decrease in Hb concentration (hematocrit) due to a greater increase in plasma volume. This decreases oxygen-carrying capacity per unit volume of blood.

Maternal iron stores are not sufficient to meet the increased demand during pregnancy and hence the serum iron and ferritin concentration falls.

The plasma volume expansion also lowers serum potassium.  

Related Pearl: Hematological changes in pregnancy

Decreases

Hemoglobin mass

Hemoglobin concentration

Total plasma protein

S.urea/creatinine/uric acid

Globulin

Albumin

Neutrophils

Platelets

Fibrinogen

Blood urea nitrogen

Factors 7,8,9,10

Factor 11,13

Insulin

S.Na/K/Ca/Mg/I2

LDL,HDL,apolipoprotiens

-

S.Transferrin and TIBC(Total

Iron binding capcity)

S.Iron, ferritin

CRP(C-Reactive protein)

  

Placental phosphatase

  

Total alkaline phosphatase

  

ESR 4x rise

questions.text: Which of the following is not a physiological change seen in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Decrease in peripheral vascular resistance is a physiological change seen in pregnancy. 

Cardiovascular parameters that increase in pregnancy are:

  • Cardiac output
  • Stroke volume
  • Heart rate

Cardiovascular parameters that decrease in pregnancy are:

  • Peripheral vascular resistance (due to smooth muscle relaxation by progesterone)
  • Both diastolic BP and systolic BP (decrease in DBP > SBP)
  • Mean arterial BP
  • Artery venous O2 gradient

Related Pearl: Cardiovascular changes in pregnancy

  • The resting pulse rate increases by 10 beats/min
  • The apex is moved laterally 
  • Cardiac output remains elevated throughout (maximum in the immediate postpartum period)
  • X-Ray shows a larger cardiac silhouette (due to benign pericardial effusion and shifted apex)
  • ECG: Slight left axis deviation

Heart sounds:

  • First heart sound: Loud with an exaggerated split
  • Second heart sound: Normal but loud
  • Third heart sound: Loud and easily heard

Murmurs:

  • A systolic murmur that was intensified during inspiration or expiration
  • A soft diastolic murmur (in 20%)
  • Continuous murmur arising from the breast vasculature (in 10%)

questions.text: A primigravida presents in the 2nd trimester complaining that her slippers do not fit anymore. On examination, her pulse is 88/min and blood pressure is 130/84mm Hg. You note bilateral pitting edema up to the level of ankles. What would you advise her?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of physiological edema during pregnancy for which the most appropriate treatment is bed rest.

It occurs due to increased venous pressure of the inferior extremities by the gravid uterus pressing on the common iliac veins.

Features of physiological edema in pregnancy are:

  • Slight degree of ankle edema
  • Usually confined to one leg, more commonly the right leg
  • Not associated with any other features of preeclampsia (like BP>140/90mm Hg, proteinuria)
  • Disappears with rest
  • Other cardiac, renal and hematological pathologies are absent

questions.text: Which of the following is not a physiological change seen during pregnancy?

choices.text: Pulmonary blood flow is increased by 2,500 mL/min
Blood flow to the skin decreases to 300 mL/min
Blood flow to the uterus increases to 750 mL/min
Renal blood flow increases by 400 mL/min

questions.solution:
The blood flow to the skin and mucous membranes increases during pregnancy to a maximum of 500 mL/min by the 36th week. Symptoms experienced during pregnancy such as increased heat sensation, sweating or having a stuffy nose can be explained by the increased blood flow.

Regional distribution of blood flow during pregnancy:

  • Uterine blood flow - increased from 50 mL/min in the non-pregnant state to about 750 mL near term. 
  • Pulmonary blood flow - increased by 2,500 mL/min.
  • Renal blood flow - increases by 400 mL/min at 16th week and remains at this level till term.

questions.text: A 23-year-old primigravida presents to the antenatal clinic at 30 weeks of gestation. During examination, which of the following cardiovascular findings would not be a cause for alarm?
questions.solution:
S3 is normally heard during pregnancy.

The third heart sound (S3) occurs due to rapid diastolic filling in hypervolemic states such as pregnancy, anemia or thyrotoxicosis. Hypervolemia is a normal physiological change during pregnancy.

The auscultation of a fixed split S2, fourth heart sound (S4) or a pericardial knock are suggestive of cardiac pathology.

Related Pearl: Cardiovascular changes in pregnancy

  • The resting pulse rate increases by 10 beats/min
  • The apex is moved laterally 
  • Cardiac output remains elevated throughout (maximum in the immediate postpartum period)
  • X-Ray shows a larger cardiac silhouette (due to benign pericardial effusion and shifted apex)
  • ECG: Slight left axis deviation

Heart sounds:

  • First heart sound: Loud with an exaggerated split
  • Second heart sound: Normal but loud
  • Third heart sound: Loud and easily heard

Murmurs:

  • A systolic murmur that was intensified during inspiration or expiration
  • A soft diastolic murmur (in 20%)
  • Continuous murmur arising from the breast vasculature (in 10%)

questions.text:
Which of the following coagulation factors are increased in pregnancy?
  1. II
  2. VII
  3. IX
  4. XI
  5. XIII
questions.solution:
All clotting factors increase in pregnancy except factors XI and XIII.

Pregnancy is a hypercoagulable state with physiological changes such as:

  • All clotting factors are increased (except factors XI and XIII)
  • Fibrinogen levels are also increased
  • The viscosity of blood decreases due to hemodilution
  • Clotting time and bleeding time is unaffected

The most common cause of decreased platelet count in pregnancy is benign gestational thrombocytopenia. This is due to hemodilution and increased platelet consumption and the women are generally asymptomatic.

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida at 38 weeks of gestation presents to the antenatal clinic with complaints of dizziness on lying down for the past one week.  She feels better on sitting up or turning to the side.  What is the cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of supine hypotension syndrome due to inferior vena caval compression. 

During late pregnancy, the gravid uterus produces a compression effect on the inferior vena cava (IVC) when the patient is in the supine position. To compensate, there will be an opening up of the collaterals of paravertebral and azygous veins.

When collaterals fail to open, venous return of the heart is reduced leading to hypotension, tachycardia, and syncope. The normal blood pressure is quickly restored by turning the patient to lateral position.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the sensitivity of uterine musculature?

choices.text: Enhanced by both estrogen and progesterone
Enhanced by estrogen and inhibited by progesterone

questions.solution:
The sensitivity of uterine musculature is enhanced by estrogen and inhibited by progesterone.

Estrogen stimulates the synthesis of myometrial contractile proteins through cAMP. This increases the excitability of uterine muscles and the frequency of action potentials.

Progesterone decreases the frequency and intensity of uterine contractions. This helps to prevent the expulsion of the implanted ovum. However, it increases the amplitude of contraction.

questions.text: A pregnant woman has cramps in her legs. What will you suggest her to relieve the pain?

choices.text: Extend knee and plantar flex foot
Flex knee and plantar flex foot

questions.solution:
Extension at the knee joint and dorsiflexion at the ankle joint helps in stretching the calf muscles which relieves the pain. 

Leg cramps are minor ailments during pregnancy mostly due to a deficiency of diffusible serum calcium or elevation of serum phosphorus. Management includes massaging the leg, stretching exercises, application of local heat, and supplementation of vitamin B1 and calcium.

questions.text: Theca lutein cysts are not associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Theca lutein cysts are not seen in hyperprolactinemia.

Theca-lutein cysts are benign ovarian lesions resulting from exaggerated physiological follicle stimulation. They are usually associated with markedly elevated serum levels of hCG.

Theca lutein cysts are found in association with:

  • Large placenta
    • Diabetes
    • Anti-D alloimmunization
    • Multifetal gestations
    • Fetal hydrops
  • Gestational trophoblastic disease - Molar pregnancy
  • Reduced hCG clearance - Chronic renal failure

They may also be found in normal pregnancy due to an exaggerated response of the ovaries to normal circulating levels of hCG.

questions.text: In which trimester does acute fatty liver manifest most commonly during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Acute fatty liver of pregnancy (AFLP) occurs most commonly in the third trimester or early postpartum period.

Risk factors include Pre-eclampsia/HELLP syndrome, male fetus, previous history of AFLP, and multiple gestations.

AFLP (acute yellow atrophy or acute fatty metamorphosis) is the most common cause of acute liver failure in pregnancy. It usually occurs in the later stages of pregnancy, particularly in the third trimester. It occurs due to fetal deficiency of long-chain acyl-coenzyme A dehydrogenase (LCHAD) or poor placental mitochondrial function.

The patients present with persistent nausea and vomiting, progressive jaundice, and epigastric pain. Features like acute hemolysis, hypoglycemia, hypertension, proteinuria, thrombocytopenia, and edema can also be present. Symptoms may progress to fulminant hepatic failure with encephalopathy, disseminated intravascular coagulation, and death.

Liver function tests such as AST, ALT, and serum bilirubin levels are raised. Hypofibrinogenemia, hypocholesterolemia, and prolonged clotting time can be seen. An elevated d-dimer is seen. Microscopy reveals a characteristic microvesicular fatty infiltration.

The condition worsens till delivery after which the hepatic dysfunction resolves. A trial of labor by induction or delivery by Cesarean is done. Intensive supportive measures including blood transfusion should be provided.

The clinical and laboratory findings of acute liver diseases in pregnancy are as follows:

Disorders  HELLP syndrome Obstetric cholestasis Acute fatty liver of pregnancy Viral hepatitis
Onset in pregnancy Mid to late Late Late Variable
Differentiating features 

Epigastric pain, hypertension,

elevated indirect bilirubin 

Pruritus  

elevated direct bilirubin

 Signs of liver failure like hypoglycemia Fever
AST (U/L)  ≤300  ≤200 200-800 2000+
Bilirubin (mg/dL) 1-4 1-5 4-10 5-20
Platelets ↓↓  Normal ↓↓  ↓
Fibrinogen Normal Normal ↓↓↓  Normal
D-dimer ↑ Normal ↑ Normal
Prothrombin time Normal Normal ↑↑  ↑
Hemolysis  ↑↑ No ↑↑↑  No

The condition worsens till delivery after which the hepatic dysfunction resolves. Appropriate management is immediate termination of pregnancy irrespective of gestational age by induction or delivery by Cesarean (for obstetric reasons) is done. Intensive supportive measures including blood transfusion should be provided.

questions.text: What does the term 'placental sign' denote?

choices.text: Alteration of fetal heart rate on pressing the head into the pelvis
Spotting on the expected date of period in early months of pregnancy
Permanent lengthening of the cord in 3rd stage of labor
Slight gush of bleeding in 3rd stage of labor

questions.solution:
Spotting on the expected date of menstruation in the early months of pregnancy is known as placental sign.

Cyclic bleeding may occur up to 12 weeks of pregnancy until the decidual space is obliterated by the fusion of decidua parietalis with decidua capsularis. The bleeding is usually scanty and lasts for a shorter duration than in a regular menstrual cycle.

Option A: Slowing of the fetal heart rate (FHR) on pressing the head down into the pelvis is suggestive of placenta previa (especially of posterior type) and is called Stallworthy’s sign. The fetal heart rate recovers as soon as the pressure is released.

Options C and D: Permanent lengthening of the cord and slight gush of bleeding in 3rd stage of labor are suggestive of separation of the placenta.
